sentences.sentence: Families, survivors and advocates were hopeful when, in June 2019, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau stood before a crowd at the release of the Final Report on Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (MMIWG) to declare he would do whatever it takes to eradicate the MMIWG crisis.
I, too, was hopeful.
I am a survivor.
I grew up in and out of the foster care system and almost lost my life when I ran away from a group home at age 11.
I was raped and held against my will by two adult men.
Now, witnessing the lives of other Indigenous women and girls being snuffed out because they're vulnerable, because of racism and inequality, reminds me that I could've been them.
I could've been murdered.My life mattered and so did theirs.
I wonder who they would've become had they not been targeted?

What would've become of Tina Fontaine, or Chantelle Bushie, or Shannon Alexander?Canada spent $93 million on a national inquiry exploring this grim phenomenon, which constituted MMIWG a genocide and found that Indigenous women and girls are 12 times more likely to go missing or be murdered than the rest of the population.
The Final Report draws a link between MMIWG and Canada's child welfare system, which has separated Indigenous children from their families for decades, exposing them to dangerous situations.

During the national inquiry into MMIWG, chief commissioner Marion Buller said, "what people have told us is that the vicious circle of violence and problems start with children going into the child welfare system.
"The Final Report concluded that "a system this broken and that places Indigenous children at greater risk for violence, now and in the future, requires nothing less than a complete paradigm shift.
"To create this paradigm shift, the report produced Calls for Justice that required 231 imperative changes, some of which are directed at social workers and those involved in child welfare.

Its recommendations include giving Indigenous communities control over family services, to apply Indigenous perspectives about what's in the best interest of the child, to provide financial support to family members of MMIWG so that they can care for children left behind, and efforts to recruit and promote Indigenous staff within family services organizations.

The Calls for Justice also outlined that all Canadians be part of the solutions.This is why my hope started to fade when the feds announced an indefinite delay in its action plan on the report's one-year anniversary.
They cited COVID-19 for interfering with the process.
Meanwhile, violence towards Indigenous women and girls continued; families, loved ones, and survivors were left in limbo.

June 3 marks two years since the Final Report was released and we're still waiting for action.A spark of optimism came when Trudeau's government announced $2.2 billion would be set aside to address MMIWG.
However, when his administration finally released their national action plan to implement the calls on June 3, it was criticized by various Indigenous leaders and political parties.
"The document released today is an offensive performance by the government to skirt responsibility and glaze over the ongoing genocide of women and girls," said Melissa Moses, Union of B.C.

Indian Chiefs women's representative.Just two days earlier on June 1, the Native Women's Association of Canada (NWAC) announced that they were leaving the national plan, citing a "toxic and dysfunctional" process, and released Our Calls, Our Actions, with 65 specific actions they plan to take to address the Calls for Justice.It's heartening that the NWAC made such a bold move, but the stalled justice is disappointing and does nothing to empower Indigenous children.

As a child in the foster care system, my family and I needed resources for healing, retribution from the violence of colonialism, and for the government to uphold its Treaty obligations signed by my ancestors.My prayer is that Canadians will wake up.
That they'll stand beside our sisters who are being taken.
We can't rely on governments for everything - this needs to come from the hearts of the people.
What will you tell your grandchildren one day when they learn you lived during a genocide?
Did you help?
Or did you look away?
